g is gravitational acceleration constant,  so m/s^2

Because it is acceleration.  m/s is simply a velocity.  A constant velocity is just meters per second.  When you accelerate, your velocity changes.  So each second, your velocity increases by a certain amount.  The change in velocity would be measured in meters per second, and since velocity itself is already in meters per second, the change in velocity would be meters per second....per second.  In other words, if you are traveling at 1 m/s, and begin to ACCELERATE at a rate that increases your velocity by 1 m/s....every second, then after one second, you'd be going 2 m/s.  After 3 seconds, 3 m/s.  Your change in velocity is 1 m/s....per second...or 1 m/s/s - or m/s².

Isn't it a negative value ?

g is not a constant.  It is an average acceleration for objects near the surface of the Earth.  It ranges from 9.764 m/s² to about 9.834 m/s² depending on where you are on Earth - as the farther you are from the center of mass (i.e., on top of a mountain), the lower the rate of acceleration.  It doesn't matter whether g is represented by a positive or negative value.  It is more common for gravitational acceleration to be negative, but it is by no means a rule.  As long as you are consistent, it doesn't matter.  If you use a negative acceleration, then you are simply defining the downward direction as negative.  If you wish to define the downward direction as positive, you will get the exact same results in any calculation.
